Great, now that you've powered the circuit and observed the DMM readings, let's take a look at what happens during this circuit's operation.

Click Continue to take a look.

Voltage is available before the toggle switch in the circuit.

A path to ground is available after the push-button switch and relay to contact(E).

When the toggle switch is closed, voltage is available:
  • From the toggle switch to the push button
  • From the toggle switch through relay contact(F)
  • From the toggle switch through the diode
    • to relay contact(A)(/li).

    A path to ground is available after the push button switch and to relay contact(E).

When the push button switch is closed, current flows through the relay coil, generating a magnetic field.

Current is unable to flow through the diode because it is reverse biased.
The magnetic field generated by current flowing through the relay coil pulls the relay armature plate in towards the coil, and closes the contacts.

Current flows through the relay contacts and the bulbs illuminate.

The diode is still in reverse bias, preventing current flow through its part of the circuit.

The relay coil's magnetic field continues to hold the contacts closed.

As the push button switch is released, the magnetic field begins to collapse.

As the magnetic field collapses, the magnetic lines of force pass over the coil and voltage is induced.
As the magnetic field collapses, the magnetic lines of force pass over the coil and voltage is induced.

While the magnetic field collapses, the induced current is in reverse direction to that of the applied voltage.

The diode gives the current a complete path and flows until the spike is dissipated.

This prevents damage to components and reduces radio frequency interference.
Which effect does adding a clamping diode parallel to the relay coil have on this circuit?
The diode provides a controlled path for current to flow when the circuit is opened untill the induced voltage dissipates.
The diode reduces the current flow when the circuit is closed, resulting in lower voltage surges.
The diode amplifies the magnetic field produced by the relay coil during circuit operation.
The diode increases the output of other loads in the circuit during relay operation.

Correct, the clamping diode prevents induced voltage spikes from damaging computers and causing radio frequency interference.
